Welcome to another episode 
of 'Back To Basics'.
My name is May Thu Kyaw,

and today we'll talk about how 
you can set up basic logs and alarms
in your AWS account.

Imagine a day 
when your system is not available,

performing poorly, 
or not knowing where to look
when things are not in a good state.

Traditional monitoring strategies 
and tools

tend to be focusing 
on the health of the physical devices

in the data center 
and in the business.

In the cloud, 
these strategies continue to be critical,

but there are other tools 
that you can leverage
to understand the health of your applications,
your cloud usage,

and get notified, 
so that you can respond to the situation.

To monitor your user and resource activity 
across your AWS infrastructure
for governance and auditing,
AWS CloudTrail can help.

It can help to monitor 
and recall account activity,
improve your security posture,

by understanding who is doing what 
and where in your AWS account.

CloudTrail is enabled by default 
for all AWS accounts,

and provides 90 days of event history 
in the CloudTrail console.

To get a complete record 
of all events in your environment,

I recommend you create a trail 
to archive changes and activity.

That way you can store 
the API events as a log
in a secure and immutable format

to be used for later analysis 
for security and compliance purposes.

Now that you know 
how to monitor your account activity,

how about your cloud resources 
and applications running on AWS?

How do you know the health 
of your application,
or perhaps performance of the system?

Amazon CloudWatch is a monitoring service 
for your cloud resources and applications
you run on AWS.

You can use CloudWatch 
to collect log and metrics
from various AWS services,
and even on-premises servers,

to help you better understand 
the health of your application.

Now, I will show you how you can use 
these two services together
to have better visibility.

You can configure CloudTrail
to send events which contain API activity
in AWS account to CloudWatch logs.

You can search and filter these log data 
by creating metric filters.

These metric filters can be used 
to create CloudWatch metrics
that you can create your own graphs,
or create CloudWatch Alarms to set notifications,

based on the metric values 
and patterns you define earlier.

For example, 
an alarm could be set to notify you

when the number of errors encounter
in your account reaches 10.
When you create an AWS account,

I recommend you 
to create monitoring alerts
for your AWS cost and usage information.

The easiest way to get started 
is AWS Budget.

It gives you the ability 
to track your cost utilization
or even set custom budgets,

so that you stay informed 
and action quickly

when your usage exceeds 
the budget thresholds.
To take a step further,

enhance your cost control 
and reduce cost surprises
using AWS Cost Anomaly Detection.
This is a free monitoring service

that leverages 
advanced machine learning technology

to identify set spend increases 
and root cause analysis.

To get started, 
step one is to create a cost monitor
to evaluate anomalies in your AWS account.

Step two is to create alert preferences 
by setting a dollar threshold.
Now you're all set to stay informed,
pinpoint potential cost drivers,

such as your specific 
AWS account services

or even a region 
that is driving the cost increases.

Now, I have discussed 
two cost control services,
but not all alerts tell the same story.

AWS Budgets notifies you when your usage 
exceeds the budget threshold.

Cost Anomaly Detection tells you 
when you're spend seems abnormal
based on your usage patterns,

so you know how to respond 
when different alarms trigger.
Let's see all things in action.

First in your AWS account, 
make sure you have CloudTrail enabled,
to have visibility into your account.

It's a key aspect of security 
and operational best practices.

CloudWatch can be used 
to monitor your cloud resources
and applications you run on AWS.

Optionally, you can send 
CloudTrail log events into CloudWatch.

CloudWatch metrics are data 
about the performance of your system,

and you can get 
more detail monitoring of your resources,
or even create your own custom metrics.

From there, create CloudWatch alarms 
to notify you and your team.
For example, use Amazon SNS topics

to send an email notification 
when the alarm changes state.

To stay informed 
with cloud financial usage,

set your AWS Budget, 
and turn on your budget alerts,
to either send you an email

or take automated action 
when you reach your threshold.

Leverage Cost Anomaly Detection
to reduce build surprises

and spend anomalies 
through the automated detection alerts.
In this episode,

we've looked at how 
you can improve the visibility,
not only in your AWS system,

but also your AWS account 
and user activity.
With these best practices,

now you know where to look, 
what to look for,

when things have changed 
in your AWS environment.

Check out the links below 
for more details.
Thank you and see you next time.
